Realization of this threat is possible in absence of protection measures related to monitoring, collection and analysis of data about information security events (absence of security event registration measures)
violator: Internal threat actor with medium capability

threats.name: Threat of unauthorized system access using third-party services
threats.description:
The threat consists of the possibility of an adversary conducting destructive software impact on the compromised system using third-party legitimate services (social networks, messengers, code repositories, etc.) used as intermediaries.
Realization of this threat is possible if the compromised system is already compromised.
violator: External threat actor with medium capability

threats.name: Threat of unauthorized access to applications installed on Smart cards
threats.description:
The threat consists of the possibility of an adversary gaining unauthorized access to applications installed on Smart cards by sending specially formed control commands (for example, specially formed SMS messages sent to SIM card).
This threat is caused by vulnerabilities in applications installed on Smart cards.
Realization of this threat is possible when using Java Card type Smart cards
violator: External threat actor with medium capability

threats.name: Threat of using compromised trusted software update source
threats.description:
The threat consists of the possibility of malicious code introduction into the information system through use of compromised trusted software update sources.
Realization of this threat is possible when using compromised trusted software update servers
violator: External threat actor with medium capability
Internal threat actor with medium capability

threats.name: Threat of machine learning model information disclosure
threats.description:
The threat consists of the possibility of an adversary disclosing information about the machine learning model used in the information (automated) system.
This threat is caused by weaknesses in access control in information (automated) systems using machine learning.
Realization of this threat is possible if the adversary has direct access to the machine learning model
violator: External threat actor with high capability
Internal threat actor with medium capability

threats.name: Threat of training data theft
threats.description:
The threat consists of the possibility of an adversary stealing training data used in the information (automated) system implementing artificial intelligence technologies.
This threat is caused by weaknesses in access control for training data used in the information (automated) system.
Realization of this threat is possible if the adversary has direct access to training data
violator: External threat actor with medium capability
Internal threat actor with medium capability

threats.name: Threat of artificial intelligence technology tool malfunction (bypass)
violator: External threat actor with high capability
Internal threat actor with medium capability

threats.name: Threat of machine learning model modification through training data poisoning
threats.description:
The threat consists of the possibility of modifying (distorting) the machine learning model used in the information (automated) system implementing artificial intelligence technologies.
This threat is caused by:
- deficiencies in machine learning process implementation;
- deficiencies in machine learning algorithm design.
Realization of this threat is possible if the adversary has the ability to impact the machine learning process
violator: External threat actor with high capability
Internal threat actor with medium capability

threats.name: Threat of machine learning model substitution
threats.description:
The threat consists of the possibility of an adversary substituting the machine learning model used in the information (automated) system implementing artificial intelligence technologies.
This threat is caused by weaknesses in access control in information (automated) systems using machine learning.
Realization of this threat is possible if the adversary has direct access to the machine learning model
violator: Internal threat actor with high capability

threats.name: Threat of unauthorized access to containers providing users with elevated privileges
threats.description:
The threat consists of the possibility of an adversary conducting destructive software impact by obtaining elevated privileges during unauthorized use of a docker container.
This threat is caused by docker containers having elevated privileges to operate in the system.
Realization of this threat is possible if the adversary has access to the docker container and privileges sufficient to work with it
violator: Internal threat actor with low capability
External threat actor with low capability

protectionMeasures.name: Identification and authentication of users who are employees of the operator
Identification and authentication of devices, including stationary, mobile and portable
Management of identifiers, including creation, assignment, destruction of identifiers
Management of authentication means, including storage, issuance, initialization, blocking of authentication means and taking measures in case of loss and (or) compromise of authentication means
Protection of feedback when entering authentication information
Identification and authentication of users who are not employees of the operator (external users)

Identification and authentication of file system objects, executable and running modules, database management system objects, objects created by application and specialized software, and other access objects
Management (creation, activation, blocking and destruction) of user accounts, including external users
Implementation of necessary methods (discretionary, mandatory, role-based or other method), types (read, write, execute or other type) and rules of access control

Management (filtering, routing, connection control, unidirectional transmission and other management methods) of information flows between devices, segments of the information system, as well as between information systems
Separation of authorities (roles) of users, administrators and persons ensuring the functioning of the information system
Assignment of minimally necessary rights and privileges to users, administrators and persons ensuring the functioning of the information system
Limitation of unsuccessful login attempts to the information system (access to the information system)

Warning the user when logging into the information system that information protection measures are implemented in the information system, and about the need to comply with the information processing rules established by the operator
Notifying the user after a successful login to the information system about their previous login to the information system
Limitation of the number of parallel access sessions for each user account of the information system
Blocking access session to the information system after a specified period of user inactivity or at their request
Permission (prohibition) of user actions allowed before identification and authentication
Support and preservation of security attributes (security labels) associated with information during its storage and processing
Implementation of secure remote access of access subjects to access objects through external information and telecommunication networks
Regulation and control of the use of wireless access technologies in the information system
Regulation and control of the use of mobile technical means in the information system
Management of interaction with information systems of third-party organizations (external information systems)
Ensuring trusted boot of computing equipment
Management of launching (accessing) software components, including defining launchable components, configuring component launch parameters, and controlling software component launches

Management of installation (installation) of software components, including defining components to be installed, configuring component installation parameters, and controlling software component installation
Installation (installation) of only authorized software and (or) its components
Management of temporary files, including prohibition, permission, redirection of writing, deletion of temporary files
Accounting for machine-readable information media
Access control to machine-readable information media
Control of movement of machine-readable information media beyond the controlled zone
Exclusion of the possibility of unauthorized familiarization with the content of information stored on machine-readable media and (or) use of information media in other information systems
Control of the use of input (output) interfaces of information to machine-readable information media
Control of input (output) of information to machine-readable information media
Control of connection of machine-readable information media
Destruction (erasure) of information on machine-readable media when transferring them between users, to third-party organizations for repair or disposal, as well as control of destruction (erasure)
Definition of security events subject to registration and their retention periods
Definition of the composition and content of information about security events subject to registration
Collection, recording and storage of information about security events during the established retention period
Response to failures in recording security events, including hardware and software errors, failures in information collection mechanisms and reaching the limit or overflow of memory volume (capacity)
Monitoring (viewing, analysis) of security event registration results and responding to them
Generation of timestamps and (or) synchronization of system time in the information system
Protection of information about security events
Ensuring the ability to view and analyze information about the actions of individual users in the information system
Implementation of antivirus protection
Updating the database of signatures of malicious computer programs (viruses)
Intrusion detection
Updating the database of decision rules
Detection, analysis of information system vulnerabilities and prompt elimination of newly discovered vulnerabilities
Control of software update installation, including updates to information protection software
Control of operability, configuration parameters and proper functioning of software and information protection means
Control of the composition of technical means, software and information protection means
Control of rules for generating and changing user passwords, creating and deleting user accounts, implementing access control rules, user authorities in the information system
Integrity control of software, including information protection software
Integrity control of information contained in databases of the information system
Ensuring the possibility of restoring software, including information protection software, in case of abnormal situations
Detection and response to the receipt of unsolicited electronic messages (emails, documents) and other information not related to the functioning of the information system (spam protection)

Control of the content of information transmitted from the information system (container, based on access object properties, and content, based on search for prohibited information using signatures, masks and other methods), and exclusion of unlawful transmission of information from the information system
Restriction of user rights to enter information into the information system
Control of accuracy, completeness and correctness of data entered into the information system
Control of erroneous user actions for entering and (or) transmitting information and warning users about erroneous actions
Use of fault-tolerant technical means
Redundancy of technical means, software, information transmission channels, means ensuring the functioning of the information system
Control of fault-free functioning of technical means, detection and localization of functioning failures, taking measures to restore failed means and their testing
Periodic backup of information to backup machine-readable information media
Ensuring the possibility of restoring information from backup machine-readable information media (backup copies) within a specified time interval
Clustering of the information system and (or) its segments
Control of the state and quality of provision of computing resources (capacities) by authorized persons, including information transmission
Identification and authentication of access subjects and access objects in virtual infrastructure, including virtualization management administrators
Access control of access subjects to access objects in virtual infrastructure, including inside virtual machines
Registration of security events in virtual infrastructure
Management (filtering, routing, connection control, unidirectional transmission) of information flows between virtual infrastructure components, as well as on the perimeter of virtual infrastructure
Trusted boot of virtualization servers, virtual machine (container), virtualization management servers
Management of movement of virtual machines (containers) and data processed on them
Integrity control of virtual infrastructure and its configurations
Backup of data, redundancy of technical means, software of virtual infrastructure, as well as communication channels within virtual infrastructure
Implementation and management of antivirus protection in virtual infrastructure
Segmentation of virtual infrastructure (segmenting virtual infrastructure) for processing information by an individual user and (or) group of users
Protection of information processed by technical means from its leakage through technical channels
Organization of a controlled zone within which stationary technical means processing information, information protection means, and means ensuring functioning are permanently located

Control and management of physical access to technical means, information protection means, functioning support means, as well as to premises and structures where they are installed, excluding unauthorized physical access to information processing means, information protection means and functioning support means of the information system and premises and structures where they are installed
Placement of information output (display) devices that excludes its unauthorized viewing
Protection from external influences (environmental impacts, power supply instability, air conditioning and other external factors)

Separation in the information system of functions for managing (administering) the information system, managing (administering) the information protection system, information processing functions and other functions of the information system
Prevention of delay or interruption of execution of high-priority processes by low-priority processes

Ensuring protection of information from disclosure, modification and imposition (input of false information) during its transmission (preparation for transmission) over communication channels extending beyond the controlled zone, including wireless communication channels
Ensuring trusted channel, route between administrator, user and information protection means (security functions of information protection means)
Prohibition of unauthorized remote activation of video cameras, microphones and other peripheral devices that can be activated remotely, and notifying users about the activation of such devices

tacticalTasks.name: Reconnaissance
tacticalTasks.description: Reconnaissance consists of techniques that involve adversaries actively or passively gathering information that can be used to support targeting. Such information may include details of the victim organization, infrastructure, or personnel. This information can be leveraged by the adversary to aid in other phases of the adversary lifecycle, such as using gathered information to plan and execute Initial Access, to scope and prioritize post-compromise objectives, or to drive and lead further Reconnaissance efforts.
relatedThreats: Threat of open port discovery and identification of bound network services
Threat of host discovery
Threat of protected object type identification
Threat of obtaining preliminary information about the protected object

tacticalTasks.name: Resource Development
tacticalTasks.description: Resource Development consists of techniques that involve adversaries creating, purchasing, or compromising/stealing resources that can be used to support targeting. Such resources include infrastructure, accounts, or capabilities. These resources can be leveraged by the adversary to aid in other phases of the adversary lifecycle, such as using purchased domains to support Command and Control, email accounts for phishing as a part of Initial Access, or stealing code signing certificates to aid in Defense Evasion.

tacticalTasks.name: Initial Access
tacticalTasks.description: Initial Access consists of techniques that use various entry vectors to gain their initial foothold within a network. Techniques used to gain a foothold include targeted spearphishing and exploiting weaknesses on public-facing web servers. Footholds gained through initial access may allow for continued access, like valid accounts and use of external remote services, or may be limited-use due to changing passwords.

tacticalTasks.name: Persistence
tacticalTasks.description: The ability to maintain a presence in the attacked infrastructure even after the attacked node is rebooted, some injected tools are found and destroyed, etc.

tacticalTasks.name: Privilege Escalation
tacticalTasks.description: Privilege Escalation consists of techniques that adversaries use to gain higher-level permissions on a system or network. Adversaries can often enter and explore a network with unprivileged access but require elevated permissions to follow through on their objectives. Common approaches are to take advantage of system weaknesses, misconfigurations, and vulnerabilities. Examples of elevated access include system/root level, local administrator, user account with admin-like access, and user accounts with access to specific system or performing specific functions. These techniques often overlap with Persistence techniques, as OS features that let an adversary persist can execute in an elevated context.

tacticalTasks.name: Defense Evasion
tacticalTasks.description: Defense Evasion consists of techniques that adversaries use to avoid detection throughout their compromise. Techniques used for defense evasion include uninstalling/disabling security software or obfuscating/encrypting data and scripts. Adversaries also leverage and abuse trusted processes to hide and masquerade their malware. Other tactics listings are included here when those techniques include the added benefit of subverting defenses.

tacticalTasks.name: Credential Access
tacticalTasks.description: Credential Access consists of techniques for stealing credentials like account names and passwords. Techniques used to get credentials include keylogging or credential dumping. Using legitimate credentials can give adversaries access to systems, make them harder to detect, and provide the opportunity to create more accounts to help achieve their goals.

tacticalTasks.name: Discovery
tacticalTasks.description: Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what's around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.
relatedThreats: Threat of cache data integrity violation
Threat of forced web browsing
Threat of using vulnerable software versions

tacticalTasks.name: Lateral Movement
tacticalTasks.description: Lateral Movement consists of techniques that adversaries use to enter and control remote systems on a network. Following through on their primary objective often requires exploring the network to find their target and subsequently gaining access to it. Reaching their objective often involves pivoting through multiple systems and accounts to gain. Adversaries might install their own remote access tools to accomplish Lateral Movement or use legitimate credentials with native network and operating system tools, which may be stealthier.

tacticalTasks.name: Collection
tacticalTasks.description: Collection consists of techniques adversaries may use to gather information and the sources information is collected from that are relevant to following through on the adversary's objectives. Frequently, the next goal after collecting data is to steal (exfiltrate) the data. Common target sources include various drive types, browsers, audio, video, and email. Common collection methods include capturing screenshots and keyboard input.

tacticalTasks.name: Command and Control
tacticalTasks.description: Command and Control consists of techniques that adversaries may use to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network. Adversaries commonly attempt to mimic normal, expected traffic to avoid detection. There are many ways an adversary can establish command and control with various levels of stealth, depending on the victim's network structure and defenses.

tacticalTasks.name: Exfiltration
tacticalTasks.description: Exfiltration consists of techniques that adversaries may use to steal data from your network. Once they've collected data, adversaries often package it to avoid detection while removing it. This can include compression and encryption. Techniques for getting data out of a target network typically include transferring it over their command and control channel or an alternate channel and may also include putting size limits on the transmission.

tacticalTasks.name: Impact
tacticalTasks.description: Impact consists of techniques that adversaries use to disrupt availability or compromise integrity by manipulating business and operational processes. Techniques used for impact can include destroying or tampering with data. In some cases, business processes can look fine but may have been altered to benefit the adversaries' goals. These techniques might be used by adversaries to achieve their end goal or to provide cover for a confidentiality breach.
